GroupHeaders.element: Show this group for each change of the following:
The list above contains the sort fields defined for the report, and the data categories they belong to.

Group Headers are used as leading or title areas for more detailed information that follows. For example, lets say the data you're interested in viewing are countries and cities. Since there are many cities for each country, you may want to see each country only once, followed by all cities for that country. In this case you would create a group header for the country data, then a detail area below for the city data. A report can have multiple group headers for varying levels of data.

Group Footers are used as trailing areas for more detailed information that preceded it. They are mainly used for aggregate data, such as sums and averages. For example, lets say the data you're interested in viewing are countries and cities. For each country, you may want the total population of all the cities within that country. To do this, you would create a group footer on country, then add the population field from the city category, and click the autosum button. A report can have multiple group footers for varying levels of data.

Repeating Groups are used for information that you want to repeat before continuing with other information in the report. For example, lets say the data you're interested in viewing are countries, cities, and towns. You may want to see each country only once, followed by all cities for that country, then all towns for that country. In this case, you would create a repeating group for cities by country, then a repeating group for towns by country. All cities will then be repeated for each country, before continuing to the next section, which is another repeating group where all towns will be repeated for each country. Each repeating section can have its own header and footer allowing aggregate values on just the information within the repeating group.
There are no sort fields defined for the report.\nHeaders, Footers, and Repeating Sections are based upon fields selected for sorting.\nPlease add a field to sort on.
Click to group on a formula that is not explicitly defined as a sort. (Advanced use only; this may cause undesired results!)

Calculates the average value of a data field. Use in a Group Footer section to get the average for the group. Use in a Report Footer section to get the average for the report.
Numeric data field to calculate the average of the values
Pass True() to force aggregation to occur for every record, rather than for each unique entity. If you don’t know what to pass here, omit this argument.
Counts the number of unique rows in a data category. Use in a Group Footer section to get the count for the group. Use in a Report Footer section to get the count for the report.
Data field in the category to count the rows. Usually the unique key field.
Pass True() to force aggregation to occur for every record, rather than for each unique entity. If you don’t know what to pass here, omit this argument.
Counts the number of unique values in a data field. Use in a Group Footer section to get the count for the group. Use in a Report Footer section to get the count for the report.
Data field to count the unique values
Pass True() to force aggregation to occur for every record, rather than for each unique entity. If you don’t know what to pass here, omit this argument.
Pass True() to count nulls as a distinct value when aggregating. If you don’t know what to pass here, omit this argument.

Gets the largest value in a data field (or alphabetically last, or latest date). Use in a Group Footer section to get the max for the group. Use in a Report Footer section to get the max for the report.
Data field to get the largest value
Pass True() to force aggregation to occur for every record, rather than for each unique entity. If you don’t know what to pass here, omit this argument.

Gets the smallest value in a data field (or alphabetically first, or earliest date). Use in a Group Footer section to get the min for the group. Use in a Report Footer section to get the min for the report.
Data field to get the smallest value
Pass True() to force aggregation to occur for every record, rather than for each unique entity. If you don’t know what to pass here, omit this argument.
Calculates the sum of the values in a data field. Use in a Group Footer section to get the sum for the group. Use in a Report Footer section to get the sum for the report.
Numeric data field to calculate the sum of the values
Pass True() to force aggregation to occur for every record, rather than for each unique entity. If you don’t know what to pass here, omit this argument.
Keep a running sum of the values in a data field. Use in a repeating section. Optionally, reset the sum to 0 at each new value of a data field or category.

Reset the sum to 0 at each new value of this field or category
Pass True() to force aggregation to occur for every record, rather than for each unique entity. If you don’t know what to pass here, omit this argument.

Calculates the variance of a data field. Variance tells you how tightly your data is clustered around the mean. Use in a Group Footer section to get the variance for the group. Use in a Report Footer section to get the variance for the report.
The Data Field containing the values for the variance calculation. Must be a numeric data type. May be an arbitrary expression that evaluates to a numeric data type.
String value to be one of 'Sample' (default) or 'Population' for sample-based or population-based variance, respectively.
Pass True() to force aggregation to occur for every record, rather than for each unique entity. If you don’t know what to pass here, omit this argument.

Calculates the standard deviation of a data field. Standard deviation tells you how tightly your data is clustered around the mean and is the square root of the variance. Use in a Group Footer section to get the standard deviation for the group. Use in a Report Footer section to get the standard deviation for the report.
The Data Field containing the values for the standard deviation calculation. Must be a numeric data type. May be an arbitrary expression that evaluates to a numeric data type.
String value to be one of 'Sample' (default) or 'Population' for sample-based or population-based standard deviation, respectively.
Pass True() to force aggregation to occur for every record, rather than for each unique entity. If you don’t know what to pass here, omit this argument.

Calculates the median value of a data field. Median tells you where the middle of your data set is. Use in a Group Footer section to get the median for the group. Use in a Report Footer section to get the median for the report.
The Data Field containing the values for the median calculation. Must be a numeric data type. May be an arbitrary expression that evaluates to a numeric data type.
Pass True() to force aggregation to occur for every record, rather than for each unique entity. If you don’t know what to pass here, omit this argument.

Calculates the mode of a data field. The mode of a set of a data set is the value that appears most frequently. A dataset may have more than one mode. A dataset with two modes may be described to be bimodal, while a dataset with more than two modes may be described as multimodal. Use in a Group Footer section to get the mode for the group. Use in a Report Footer section to get the mode for the report.
The Data Field containing the values for the mode calculation. May be an arbitrary expression.
Pass True() to force aggregation to occur for every record, rather than for each unique entity. If you don’t know what to pass here, omit this argument.

element.tooltip: Check this box if you have multi-series data with common data labels among series. For example, consider charting house values as a function of location and building type. We choose location as the series labels and building type as data labels. Since each location uses the same building types, we check the 'Align Data Labels Across Series' box to align like data labels in the chart. On the other hand, if we want to chart city populations where we use country name as the series labels and city name as the data labels, we leave the box unchecked. This is because the data labels (city name) used for one series (country name) have no relation to those used in others.

element.tooltip: Called after all data is retrieved and combined from all data sources. Passes a System.Data.DataTable to event. Expects a System.Data.DataTable return value, which represents modified data.
Called when a report fails validation while being loaded for editing or execution.
Called at beginning of report execution processing. Expects a string return value, which if null will continue processing, or if not null represents language ID or text to display.
Called at end of report execution processing. Passes a boolean value indicating whether any data qualified for the report to event. Return any value, which is ignored.
Called after data is retrieved from a Web Service Method. Allows processing on data, such as decompression, decryption, etc.

Called after SQL statement due to report execution is constructed allowing any changes to be made. Passes a string representing SQL into event. Expects a string return value representing modified SQL statement.

Called after SQL statement due to filter dropdown is contructed allowing any changes to be made. Passes a string representing SQL into event. Expects a string return value representing modified SQL statement.

Called after SQL statement due to parameter dropdown is contructed allowing any changes to be made. Passes a string representing SQL into event. Expects a string return value representing modified SQL statement.

Called after Ok button in Filter execution dialog is clicked. Passes report object to event. Expects a string return value, which if null will continue processing, or if not null represents language ID or text to display.

Called after Ok button in Parameter execution dialog is clicked. Passes report object to event. Expects a string return value, which if null will continue processing, or if not null represents language ID or text to display.
Called when the report parameters are loaded but before any processing has occurred. Passes report parameters object to event. Return any value, which is ignored.
Called at beginning of Scheduled report execution. Passes SchedulerJob object containing information about the schedule including the associated report object.
Called upon completed execution of a scheduled report prior to further processing regardless of whether or not the report executed successfully.
Called upon sucessful execution of a scheduled report prior to further processing.
Called just before rendering a chart. Expects a List<ChartDataPoint> return value, which represents modified data.
Called just after configuration file is loaded. Return any value, which is ignored.
Called after configuration file is loaded, any changes are made, and host application container is redirected to Exago Reporting application. Return any value, which is ignored.

Called just before renaming a report. Passes current report name and new report name to event. Expects a string return value, which if null will continue processing, or if not null represents language ID or text to display.
Called after a report is renamed. Passes old report name and new report name to event. Return any value, which is ignored.

Called after data fields are retrieved for a specific data object. Passes the System.Data.DataTable containing the names and metadata of the data fields, a WebReports.Api.Reports.Entity object, which contains the data object name and alias, and a reference to a WebReports.Api.Data.DataObjectBase object, which calls the event. Expects a System.Data.DataTable return value, which represents the modified data.
Called to retrieve a user preference, if the User Setting 'User Preference Storage Method' is set to 'Server Event'. Passes the ID of the user preference to the event. Expects a string return value.
Called to set a user preference, if the User Setting 'User Preference Storage Method' is set to 'Server Event'. Passes the ID and value of the user preference to the event. Return value is ignored.
Called before a report is saved. Expects a string return value, which if null will continue processing, or if not null represents language ID or text to display.
Called after reports created in Exago have been loaded into the report tree object, for the purpose of allowing additional items to be loaded into the report tree.

Called when an application exception is thrown. Passes the System.Exception and WebReports.Api.Common.Logger to the event. Expects a boolean return value, which if true, will not continue logging the error.
Called prior to exporting a CSV cell for the purpose of overriding the standard export results.

Settings that apply to multiple Report Designer types or are applied regardless of the Report Designer type

IIS Virtual Directory or absolute path that points to location of report parent folder, or a web service or assembly that is used for report and folder storage and retrieval. Format for web service is: 'url=http://WebServiceUrl.asmx'. Format for assembly is assembly=AssemblyFullPath.dll;class=Namespace.ClassName
A virtual or absolute path to store temporary files. Leave blank to use the default Temp relative application path.

Optionally specify a cloud-based service for storing temporary files. Service can be a Web Service, Assembly or MS Azure. Leave blank to use the default or Temp path setting (if set). Format for web service is: 'url=http://WebServiceUrl.asmx'. Format for assembly is assembly=AssemblyFullPath.dll;class=Namespace.ClassName. Format for Azure is 'type=azure;credentials='UseDevelopmentStorage=true;DevelopmentStorageProxyUri=http://123.4.5.6'
The names of language files, separated by commas, to load from the Languages directory (eg. en-us, en-us-getting-started)

Overrides a portion of the temporary URL used for storing images for HTML exports. Can override just the scheme (i.e. https), or full URL (i.e. http://MyServer/Exago/Temp). Leave blank to have Exago compute automatically.
True will allow users direct access to Exago. False will require users to direct through ApiRedirect.aspx for interfacing with Exago API.

element.tooltip: Text that appears in browser title bar. Leaving blank will default to 'Exago'.

Default value for number of decimal places used for currency fields; leave blank to keep variable by field.

Whether or not to use sample data when designing visualizations in a dashboard. Set to true if performance issues from users triggering many report executions in a design session are a concern.

Comma delimited string of default map CSS colors.

element.tooltip: Autofill the Microsoft SQL Server data provider information using the preselected setting
Prefill Microsoft SQL Server data provider settings to use the Microsoft MSSQL data connector
Sets the Microsoft SQL Server Data Provider name

Sets the Microsoft SQL Server Table Schema Retrieval properties. Takes the format:

'Collection:"collection",Restrictions:["restriction1",...,"restrictionx"],NameColumn:"name",SchemaColumn:"schema"'

These parameters map to SqlConnection.GetSchema concepts within the ADO.NET framework. The collection and restriction variables map to the input parameters for the SqlConnection.GetSchema call. The name and schema variables map to specific columns returned from the SqlConnection.GetSchema call.

Surrounding a value with the "@" character will map that value to the corresponding property within the datasource connection string.

'Collection:"collection",Restrictions:["restriction1",...,"restrictionx"],NameColumn:"name",SchemaColumn:"schema"'

These parameters map to SqlConnection.GetSchema concepts within the ADO.NET framework. The collection and restriction variables map to the input parameters for the SqlConnection.GetSchema call. The name and schema variables map to specific columns returned from the SqlConnection.GetSchema call.

Surrounding a value with the "@" character will map that value to the corresponding property within the datasource connection string.

Convert some filter formulas to SQL and evaluate them in the database. Click here for important security information.
Indicates whether to include null values for 'not equal', or 'not one of' filters.

Allows the parameter position to be dynamically assigned for stored procedures, web services, or assemblies. This setting is mandatory for web services and assemblies, and optional for stored procedures.

Name of stored procedure, web service, or assembly parameter to pass column delimited data column string through. This allows the stored procedure, web service, or assembly to just return data selected by user before reaching Exago which can increase report execution processing speed, and reduce server resources.

Name of stored procedure, web service, or assembly parameter to pass filter string through. The data passed is limited to the specific data object called. This allows the stored procedure, web service, or assembly to filter data before reaching Exago which can increase report execution processing speed, and reduce server resources.

Name of stored procedure, web service, or assembly parameter to pass full filter string through. The data passed includes filters for all data objects, not just for the specific one called. This allows the stored procedure, web service, or assembly to filter data before reaching Exago which can increase report execution processing speed, and reduce server resources.

Name of stored procedure, web service, or assembly parameter to pass sort string through. This is for information purposes only as Exago sorts data upon return from stored procedure, web service, or assembly.
Name of stored procedure, web service, or assembly parameter to pass name of report data category through. This is for informational purposes only.
Name of stored procedure, web service, or assembly parameter to pass ID of data object through. This can be used for assigning a single method to serve multiple data objects.
Name of stored procedure, web service, or assembly parameter to pass requested row limit through.
Name of stored procedure, web service, or assembly parameter to pass requested row start index through for row range selection.

element.tooltip: Default setting for how Exago finds schema information for Data Objects. Datasource: Query the Data Object for schema (traditional method). Metadata: Get all schema information from Column Metadata. Note that individual Data Object settings can override this default.

Tells Exago how to build schema for this Data Object. Default: Use the default setting. Datasource: Query the Data Source. Eliminates the need to maintain schema data but can result in additional database or method calls. Metadata: use Column Metadata exclusively. Reduces the number of runtime database or method calls but requires setting and maintaining of schema information.

div.h2: Protect your data from unauthorized SQL injection
div.p: Before enabling Report-Level SQL please read carefully and consider the following information.
This feature allows report writers to execute arbitrary SQL commands against data sources they can access. By default this is ALL sources except those you have specifically excluded.
Contact your database administrator to ensure that the connection string has READ-ONLY access. Do not enable Report-Level SQL without a restricted connection string for each allowed source.

Furthermore, because Report-Level SQL bypasses the Admin Console data model, Role (row-based) and column tenancy restrictions on data objects have no effect. Therefore, ensure that the connection string also restricts viewing and joining to unauthorized tables and schema.

Exclude unauthorized sources from Report-Level SQL by entering their names, surrounded by quotes (") and separated by commas (,), in the Admin Console field Data Sources to Exclude from Custom SQL Object Creation. Example:
Note: This prohibits creation, but not execution, of Report-Level SQL reports with these sources.

You can deny Roles access to Report-Level SQL by setting the Role field Allow Creation of Custom SQL Objects in Advanced Reports to False. This prohibits creation and execution of reports with Report-Level SQL. To permit execution, enable the Role Objects setting Allow User to View Report-Level Custom SQL Objects.

p.em: Please be cautious with your data.

div.p: Click here for a shareable version of this document.
Before enabling formula conversion to SQL please read carefully and consider the following information.
div.h2: Protect your data from unauthorized SQL injection
div.p: This feature converts some Exago formulas, such as If(a, b, c) to SQL, such as (CASE WHEN a THEN b ELSE c END), so that they can be evaluated in the database for improved performance. Function arguments are inserted into the SQL as-is. Without proper precautions, users could potentially inject malicious SQL into formulas in order to modify or view unauthorized data.

Contact your database administrator to ensure that the connection string has READ-ONLY access. Do not enable formula conversion to SQL without a restricted connection string for each accessible source.

There are innate differences between how Exago and databases evaluate formulas. Equivalent formulas may return inconsistent data in some situations. Mathematical equations may have differing levels of precision, which can alter the result. Date functions are known to have some divergent behavior as well.

Test this feature in a staging environment to ensure that there are no material abnormalities in formula output. If you are experiencing issues, either disable this feature or consider editing the function conversion table to better reflect your desired output:
Click here for a shareable version of this document.

Tips.element: Would you like to skip the tutorial?
Tutorial settings can be found in User Preferences

Here are your data fields.

Add data columns to your report by dragging fields from the left pane onto the canvas.

Use this button to switch between sample data and Live Data.

Building reports is quicker with Live Data turned off.

Select the Save icon to name your ExpressView and place it in a folder.

Select the Export icon to download your ExpressView to your computer.
If Live Data is enabled, refresh the report to see the latest data.
Select the Visualization icon to add a chart that fits the current report data. You can toggle the chart on or off using this icon.
Use the Selected Section menu to format the selected column, header, or footer. You can adjust the font and style, apply data formatting, or transform the data with a formula.
Use the Style menu to apply a theme to the entire report or adjust the color of the radial menu icons and data rows.

Sorts control how data is ordered on the report. Use the Sorts menu to select which fields are sorted first and in which direction.

Example: To see the most recent hires in each department, you might first sort by department (ascending from A to Z) and then by hire date (descending from today to the past).

Use the Filters menu to limit the data displayed.

Include values using filters like "is one of". Exclude values using filters like "does not contain". Limit the report to the highest or lowest values in a set using Top/Bottom filters.
Use the Visualization menu to select a different chart type, adjust your chart's appearance, and change which data is used in the chart.

Use the Settings menu to customize export settings.

You can also rename your ExpressView, move or copy it, or export it to an Advanced Report.

Would you like to see this tutorial the next time you open ExpressView?

Select the circular icon to perform quick actions on this field. Swiping up will group and summarize your data by the selected field.

Example: With two columns, Genre and Title, grouping by the Genre shows "Autobiography" as the first group of related Titles, followed by the remaining groups.

Select the totals to change how the data in each column is summarized.

You can count all the values, count only distinct (unique) values, or show the largest or smallest value, and for numeric fields, show the sum or average value.
You’ve just grouped by the selected column! Now you can select subtotals for each value in this field.

The radial menu is different for groups. Swiping up will move the field higher up the grouping tree, and swiping left will ungroup the field.

Example: Say Employees are grouped first by City, then by Department. "Albany," for example, has employees from three different Departments. Swiping up on the Department field makes it the primary group. Now the "Advertising," Department, for example, has employees in five different cities.
You’ve just added a filter! Now use the Filters menu (F key) to select a filter type and one or more values to include or exclude from your report.

This column is now the primary sort on your report.

Click the arrow icon to change sort direction. Edit the order in which columns are sorted using the radial menu or the Sorts menu (S key).
